video_info.title: Figma announces a CMS and a vibe coder? Oh boy
video_info.description:
Figma wasn't able to get acquired by Adobe, which means they need to find some way to make money. Today they just announced a website builder, CMS, and vibe coding tool...

Thank you Mobbin for sponsoring! Check them out at: https://soydev.link/mobbin

SOURCES
https://techcrunch.com/2025/05/07/figma-releases-new-ai-powered-tools-for-creating-sites-app-prototypes-and-marketing-assets/
https://www.figma.com/release-notes/?title=config-2025
https://www.figma.com/make/
https://www.figma.com/sites/

Want to sponsor a video? Learn more here: https://soydev.link/sponsor-me

Check out my Twitch, Twitter, Discord more at https://t3.gg

S/O Ph4se0n3 for the awesome edit üôè

comment.author: @mvstermlnd
comment.text:
Hello Theo!
Did Shopify kill designers? Not at all. No AI will ever be able to do that either. Why? Because designers use multiple tools to make a website look unique, whether it's pictures, videos, or whatever else.

Of course, we‚Äôll lose all the "all-knowing," egoistic clients (which has been our dream for decades), because sooner or later, those pricks will still hire a junior designer who agrees to their shitty rates.

When it comes to tools like Framer or Webflow, we‚Äôll always design websites and products in Figma. Remember Sketch, Adobe XD, Photoshop? Figma dominates not just because it holds the entire design system, but because it‚Äôs hands down the fastest way to design a full website, product, or whatever you‚Äôre building, from start to finish. We use it to create final, high-fidelity designs, not just rough ideas. Once that‚Äôs done, we either paste them into Framer or hand off the Figma file to a developer. (And Figma will eventually cut out that last step: the devs.)

So honestly, you‚Äôve got it completely backwards. It‚Äôs actually front-end and even some back-end developers who are at risk.
Designers, like myself, are increasingly using AI to implement JavaScript libraries, React components, and more without relying on devs.

The only developers who‚Äôll remain essential are those working on complex systems like dashboards, infrastructure, or deep backend logic.
But even that might be temporary. In the end, we‚Äôll reach a point where designers become hybrid creators, vibe coders, doing it all.

Code is a math language. It‚Äôs all documentation, easily stored and trained. Design, on the other hand, is art.
Sure, AI can generate photorealistic stock images or flashy ads, but you‚Äôre assuming that even semi-serious design studios will just whisper to AI, ‚ÄúHey, make me a sexy e-commerce site for my gym with hot, realistic photos.‚Äù

But there will always be pixels or layout quirks that trigger your OCD. Tons of little things that take a month to get just right.
What I‚Äôm saying is, even if that day comes, design studios will still mostly hire designers to do the manual adjustments while using AI for the coding.

replies.author: @mvstermlnd
replies.text:
You redeemed yourself after the 10th minute :D

But also, your view that Figma is scared to evaporate designers is so stupid. Not because designers are the majority of their client base, but because designers will be needed as long as humans exist. And it‚Äôs not just designers who use Figma. The whole company uses it: content writers, marketing teams, UX, UI teams, even the janitors are part of Figma.

Your basic argument is that Figma is scared to remove the brain of companies. No. They literally can‚Äôt live without the brain. There‚Äôs no professional product without it.
You sound like one of those ancient devs who thinks design was always easy to make and can be easily replaced by AI. 
Even if a company chooses to use AI images or illustrations, do you know how many design styles there are? The manual edits? Animations? Lottie, Rive? Designers do those.

The devs I used to work with 10 years ago, some lazy pricks, of course they‚Äôd be happy with mobile-designed desktop websites and AI-generated stock images.
But it was the designers who innovated all the crazy shit they‚Äôve been complaining about for years. Designers forced them to expand their skills.
Otherwise, if they were in charge, they‚Äôd finish a Word-page-like website in 3 days, grab the money, and not give a fvck.

Devs were always there to serve us, and AI tools will do the same.

No serious small company will accept a basic premade template that AI duplicates and modifies for them, even if it looks gorgeous.
Companies want to stand out and look unique. It‚Äôs the same reason why people don‚Äôt buy bulk-made t-shirts from China. 
Everyone wants their own custom style, built around their brand guidelines.

comment.author: @ThePragmaticDigitalDesig-uz1tm
comment.text: I think it comes down to how much attention you want in the experience. If you just want screens that flow together and generally work okay, then go with AI. To fine-tune the experience, the skills of a designer will be needed. In some ways, an analogy could be cars: if all you want is a cheap car, you can get one that is mass-produced for a low cost. But if you want something more custom or, in the context of cars, luxurious, you have to go with a premium hand-built model (e.g., Ferrari, Rolls-Royce, etc.). AAD (AI Assisted Design) will bring the concept of mass production to digital design by creating an automated but lower-end final result. This may be good enough for many businesses and goals. But there will likely always be a need for human designers to make the best digital experiences.

comment.text:
Dude I‚Äôve been watching your channel for awhile now I have to say this is the worst explanation you‚Äôve done of Figma. Also you‚Äôve disrespected the entire design space. 

Do you really think a designer is handing over a JPEG to a developer?!?!   How can you just gloss over the interaction, the transitions and working with the marketing teams to create a design system that syncs. Also how can you just completely not talk about Figma buzz‚Ä¶

People today who can barely use tools like squarespace do not have the capacity to use Figma which is fare more advanced tools for building websites and products. People like you are why designers constantly feel discouraged and disrespected in the tech space.

replies.author: @ggggg-qw7hl
replies.text: He had a video the other day talking about his career experience and not discounting Theo he is very knowledgable but he really has worked mostly in one large org Twitch which paints his view of the world and then becoming a youtuber and his own products the past 4 years. He has gotten lots of revenue from his own products he's launched that all have pretty minimal design to them so he likely see's design as a bit of a nice to have but not critical to a business. It's definitely a bias he has and I agree this video is pretty poor explanation, so much more in depth interesting things to go into but quite a reductive take where he usually brings good context and insight. I guess he is a dev at the end of the day so more in the know with the dev side of things rather than design but it definitely makes me double take a bit haha

comment.author: @tarabooartarmy3654
comment.text: In my experience, Replit has been MUCH less error-ridden than Bolt, Lovable, v0, etc. I was pulling my hair out with the others, and I feel like most of the issue seemed to be between the services and Supabase and Firebase. Since Replit defaults to PostgreSQL, it seems to have WAY fewer errors.

replies.author: @tarabooartarmy3654
replies.text: SEO might not even be a major concern in a few years. People are sick of searching and finding mostly AI-written content and commercial content and they're instead starting to go directly to trusted sources for information (meaning whomever they, themselves, trust). And it's become incredibly difficult for new sites to rank if there's any notable competition.

replies.author: @heavylog1c
replies.text: @@tarabooartarmy3654 True. My clients never rely on ranking in Google, they have other paths to get new clicks. But Figma's "not SEO ready" is on another level. They are doing a crime against web right now. Their headers are not even headers, they are spans inside div, inside div, inside div, inside div. Their hover effects done with JS, not CSS. And all their animations are in JS. If they will leave it like that, this will give birth to tons of crappy sites on interwebs. I hope it's just an "alpha pre-build visualization of what's comming". If not, then I don't think Figma will even survive with this low-quality product. Maybe it's their last effort to get some more money from designers while this profession is still relevant, I dunno.

comment.author: @plusone.network
comment.text: The real elephant in the room: Adding all of these new "features" to a "one trick pony" aka a single feature product/company does not make it an "ecosystem" or "platform" no matter how hard you want, wish or market it to be...

replies.author: @tarabooartarmy3654

replies.author: @plusone.network
replies.text: @@tarabooartarmy3654Okay, "evolving" from a one-trick pony into  a bigger fullstack pony that still just sells a canvas + AI wrapper. Everyone basically does some one thing slightly different, charges for it when/if they can, and to survive when they cant anymore they add on the bells and whistles like SSO or "team-player" ability usually as a business or enterprise feature and call themselves a platform

comment.author: @skylartkitchen
comment.text:
From a developer‚Äôs perspective, it‚Äôs easy to overlook the 90% of design work that isn‚Äôt immediately visible. Designing outside of a T3 chat interface involves a lot of nuanced effort and collaboration. Far more than AI can currently replicate. In the near term, AI will likely help designers by streamlining tedious or repetitive tasks, but the core of design (critical thinking, taste, and creative problem solving) isn‚Äôt going anywhere. Designers are here to stay.

On the other hand, I think developers may be facing a very different trajectory when it comes to how AI will impact their work.

replies.author: @ElliotOffen
replies.text: 100% spot on

comment.author: @CartIceCream
comment.text:
I don‚Äôt know, Theo ‚Äî I think you're missing Figma‚Äôs real play here. They're not just covering small competitors like Lovable or Bolt; they‚Äôre shifting from being a ‚Äúdesign tool‚Äù to a product collaboration platform. It‚Äôs not defense, it‚Äôs evolution.

This whole ‚Äúdesign is disappearing‚Äù talk? It‚Äôs more like executional design is being automated, while strategic and system-level design is becoming more valuable (infact Figma spoke about "Figma Make Ideas"). The problem is, not every company knows how to use that kind of design, and these companies are usually the worst ones.

Bottom line: design isn‚Äôt dying ‚Äî it‚Äôs mutating. And Figma isn‚Äôt killing it, they‚Äôre just killing the old-school version of it.

comment.author: @OggVorbis69
comment.text:
Very nice, but the architecture must be modulirised, someone tell them, to separate the principle builder from the code generator. Like a compiler. You parce the Metadata of the design and build the ui structure.


Then the back end, with a human selection, chooses the selected ui technology, which in this case is the current flavout of the month js framework, and generate the ui based on that selection.

If they hardcoded only single thing, like this react based Javascript, that will be a rubish straw away when the next js framework arrives or we finally get rid of this pain to try to write software in Javascript at all.


The splitting of the builder and Ai in two, with simple and fast to replicate last actual code emitter will allow figma to have long lasting, maintainabke solution.

Fixed. Javascript only with some kind of framework (fixed) is a dead end.

comment.author: @Maxi855
comment.text:
The thing with product design specifically is that it's not just about creating pretty UIs, there's a lot of complexity in the job which I believe (probably not the case in the future) will not be easily replaceable by AI. Sure, you can quickly prompt a UI, but many design decisions are driven by factors such as taste, business needs, user input, a desire for joy and expressivity that I think will be hard to replicate. There's too much human input in design. On the other hand, development is a much more logic-driven action, where to achieve X you need to do Y and Z. 

I think what will happen is that those who want the easiest cheapest route will take the AI route (small companies or quick projects) but those who truly want to create products that have an impact and that have a meaning will still rely on PDs.

replies.author: @readywhen
replies.text: Yeah, no true problem solving thus far. Which is where most money is generated.

comment.author: @ET_AYY_LMAO
comment.text: Figma is a tool for lazy designers who cannot be bothered to learn two of the most easiest and intuitive languages out there CSS and HTML. If you have designers who insist on figma even if you offer them time and resources to learn the trade, then by god - fire them. If you continue to use Figma after everything you are a schmuck, they are coming for the customers of their customers lmao.

replies.author: @ggggg-qw7hl
replies.text: you sound like you havent worked in the real world where we have division of labor. Both routes are valid. Figma was product market fit for a reason. HTML CSS is overkill when you just need to conceptualise 20 different ideas quickly and then refine down to 10 then 5 then 1. It's a silly dichotomy you are trying to paint as a binary

replies.author: @ET_AYY_LMAO
replies.text: @@ggggg-qw7hl I worked with a lot of designers and the best designers I ever worked with had the capacity to write excellent CSS and HTML. The problem is that there is two types of designers graphical designers and multimedia designers. If you cannot be bothered to learn something as fundamental as CSS in webdesign, you shouldnt be anywhere near the drawingboard - Working with graphic designers on multimedia especially the web is annoying, they dont know how even shadows or borders work, they never consider the multitude of screen formats, they are not cut out for the job, get a multimedia designer - They are even taught HTML and CSS along with the relevant design principles.

replies.author: @ET_AYY_LMAO
replies.text: @@ggggg-qw7hl I worked with a lot of designers actually and the smoothest experience has always been with multimedia designers. Graphic designers and the web do not mix. Back in the day they would come up with stuff in adobe illustrator for instance, that was simply impossible to do with CSS - Sure Figma might be a cure to that, but why not just get a real multimedia designer instead of a graphic designer? Why vendor lock yourself to Figma instead of getting a designer that knows the canvas they are working on? That seems more efficient timewise and monetary to me.

replies.author: @ET_AYY_LMAO
replies.text:
@@ggggg-qw7hl I also find that graphic designers are too much fixated to their usual canvas and has a hard time grasping that there is infact many different viewport ratios that people would want to use their site on. I worked at the biggest national TV station in my country for half a decade and I had to explain designers that some people, especially the visually impaired - Prefer to read news articles in landscape mode so its kind of important that it works too. She was flabberghasted!

Back in the days before decent zooming in browsers, having multiples of 4s in pixel sizes for images was kind of important if you didnt want the pictures to look blurry in other zoom levels, trying to explain stuff like this to graphic designers is like trying to explain quantum theory to your cat.

replies.author: @ET_AYY_LMAO
replies.text: @@ggggg-qw7hl I would actually claim that CSS+HTML is PERFECT if you want to quickly conceptualise and refine an idea. You dont even have to lift your hands from the keyboard using CSS+HTML.

comment.author: @robertholtz
comment.text: Figma has owned Designers for years now and bested many competitors to get there. And, while I agree that AI looms large over both Designers and Developers, what is really happening here is the rise of Webflow and its own competitors of Designer-centric low-code page builders. For years, the Agency go-to has been Figma + Webflow. But, as Webflow and its like have improved by leaps and bounds, Designers have started to cut Figma out entirely. Designing directly in Webflow's aptly named Designer interface. This is super compelling to Designers, especially since Webflow also has a mature CMS that is not as easy/cheap or ubiquitous as Wordpress but offers the flexibility for the end-customer you describe. So Figma has woken up to the threat and come to realize that if the web builders are going to walk away with the Designers, Figma has to start treating Webflow as a rival and match their page building capabilities. IMO Webflow should acquire them or vice versa. Webflow is a much more acquisitive company. I built a utility library that helps Developers get around some of the constraints inherent to Webflow's Designer-centric bias which used to be part of the no-code now low-code. Indeed the future is a great design to publish tool to design pixel perfect front ends with the full prowess or a professional dev stack, which is the bridge my library solves for. The point is, Figma no longer has a lock on Designers so if the want to survive they must take on the likes of Webflow. The problem is they are starting very late and that's without the very valid points you've made about AI.

comment.author: @zhanezar

comment.author: @joshmadrid5253
comment.text:
I don‚Äôt think they threaten anyone. Most web designers today know how to code and design in Figma, maybe not for complex tasks, but definitely for most client-requested changes. If they can‚Äôt do it, they‚Äôll often turn to AI before going to a developer. That‚Äôs exactly what Figma did, like you mentioned at 10:00. Designers are generally cheaper than developers and often charge less per hour. I think you‚Äôre underestimating designers.

Figma Make doesn‚Äôt turn designers into developers. It produces packages designed for Figma sites, not other projects. So while I can‚Äôt just drop Figma Make into a different project, I might be able to use Claude or Cursor to have AI convert it to something more compatible. Figma isn‚Äôt trying to scare developers away. They are trying to help designers feel less intimidated by code. So Lovable is still best for those who want a prompt-developed app.

I recommend watching the ‚ÄúConfig 2025: From Prompt to Code with Figma Make and Sites‚Äù video on their playlist. Also, check out Figma MCP tools for Cursor. They help designers turn their Figma designs into code within VS Code to build screens. I think what would be really cool is designing in VS Code on a canvas like Figma, and there is a developer out there working on this so designers can design and code at the same time.

A UX/UI designer‚Äôs job isn‚Äôt just to make things look good. It‚Äôs to make them usable through research and testing before development. This often saves time, and if you skip this step, your users become your testers, and those tests don‚Äôt always go well. This protects clients from themselves because the best business solution isn‚Äôt always the obvious one. Sometimes what sounds great on paper is bad for the user.

From what you shared about your experience at Twitch, it sounds like you had bad UX designers who failed to advocate for user needs with the dev team. You mentioned you haven‚Äôt hired a designer in a while, but to me, that just means you became the UX designer, not that the role or the need went away.

Designers who think ‚Äúdesign is dead‚Äù are usually just designers who prefer to be told what to build. They think it‚Äôs all about making it look good and tricking the user into thinking it works well, instead of thinking strategically about the unique needs of their users.

Sorry if this comes off a bit much. Honestly, I didn‚Äôt plan to write all this, but I felt like maybe hearing from someone who works as a UX Designer, who also codes and actually loves doing it, might be worth something. I started following you because of your love for code and how much you care about users, and that‚Äôs something I really respect.

comment.author: @Viviko
comment.text: Wait‚Ä¶ so‚Ä¶ why didn‚Äôt Figma just try to buy Bolt or Lovable‚Ä¶ ?

replies.text: Figma is out on the streets trying to get bought themselves. They don‚Äôt have any money like that.

replies.author: @joshmadrid5253
replies.text: They don‚Äôt want to be Lovable and Bolt. Figma Make doesn‚Äôt generate production-ready code for apps; it‚Äôs limited to Figma Sites and rapid prototyping. That‚Äôs a missed opportunity. Figma should ship an out-of-the-box connection to Cursor‚Äîor follow Tom Krcha‚Äôs lead and build a Design Mode inside Cursor‚Äîso designers and developers can work in the same environment, or even merge roles entirely. I teach my design students to code for this very reason: while they aren‚Äôt developers, knowing code lets them iterate, collaborate with AI, and adapt as our fields continue to converge.

comment.author: @ggggg-qw7hl
comment.text:
I think you miss a bit of context in terms of the hierarchy of visual coding tools like Framer and Webflow. They are probably more where the Figma team started seeing they need to move on this space. Sites and Make are definitely influenced by Lovable, Bolt and V0 etc as you say this year is when Figma seemed to wake up to but those tools are still kind of fun but mostly still fluff imo. 

As a designer I definitely use V0 to formalise some of the more complex interactions since Figma is bad for prototyping but all the building apps struggle to properly recreate UI which naturally comes from Figma anyway. Adding the actual code these tools spit out into existing development environments is still rework. They are great ways to ideate and collaborate but ultimately all these tools are placeholders which you basically end up learning that it's probably better to just use Cursor where it has access to your actual codebase for projects of note and scale.

I also think and you would know this well that Enterprise is where a lot of the chunkier problems to solve are for designers and developers alike with the added fun of these tools use-cases working through the layers of bureaucracy. 

All that to say, just like Shopify, Fiver, Squarespace etc weren't the end of developers, these tools wont be the end of PMs, Designers, Developers etc where we have always been - at the end of the scale where you need to do more complex problems and use cases rather than the 10,000th landing page or dashboard widget or dare I say a chat wrapper interface ;)

replies.author: @smtkumar007
replies.text: ‚Äã@@MrZerged no use my company have literally fired 2/3 of backend and 1/3 of frontend devlopers and they got us cursor and winsurf subscription , even the 2 ui/ux designers we had have gone cause bolt is not easily able to do the desing part but also able do 10-20% react part then our frontend devs takes over from there, And our productivity has not taken a hit even after that. So bascially we are fine with lesser team. my guess is IT is a dead field u would not need this much engineer in this AI era. better to stick with medical or other field were field work is needed.  Even the number of clients that we had last year has become 1/2, competition has increase cause AI has literally f** the pricing and made an equal playing field for most companies , now a smaller company can also bid and execute task which was one time not possible due to lesser man & brain power.

replies.author: @joshmadrid5253
replies.text: Learn to write code and use AI as a UX designer. If you think your job is going to be extinct, you might have misunderstood the point of your role: it‚Äôs not just about making things look good but about making things users want to use. Your job is to be a user‚Äôs advocate in a room full of business people and developers who may not understand why a user wants to use a tool a certain way. You need writing that is clear and a flow that works for users‚Äînot simply the easiest business solution or easiest-to-develop solution. Also tie your performance to metrics you can influence‚Äîlike returning-user rate and NPS, which show whether users find the app helpful.

replies.author: @sidewaysdesign
replies.text: TBH, when AI can successfully create designs and working code, the less the markup matters. Human-readable code doesn't matter when no humans need to read it.

replies.author: @GregStenson
replies.text: @@sidewaysdesign Yeah, but for now, code needs to play nice with accessibility, page speed, and SEO. Otherwise, generating site in Figma Sites by ‚Äúvibe coding‚Äù is just going to result in ‚Äúvibe sites‚Äù where I hope the builder/owner isn't trying to sell anything or rank anywhere, and doesn't care (or even know) about accessibility laws.

replies.author: @SiteStudio
replies.text:
@@sidewaysdesign The markup needs to be correct for it to be considered working code. They go hand in hand. I'm not even referring to human-readable code, although that is important for debugging. It's not even semantically correct. Which it needs to be in a world of accessibility, page speed, and SEO.

Otherwise all you'll end up with is a bunch of clients screaming at you about about why no one can find their website.
